Dear Mohammed,

 

Hope all is well and that you are having a good start of the year.

Please find here below comments inserted in your text in Red, for your kind perusal.

However, I would like to stress on the point that all previous projects with Chalhoub Group, being in UAE and/or in KSA had the same T&Cs as per our Tawreed Offer, and can confirm that no dispute ever happened or could happen in the future, given our Cemented Long Term Partnership.

 

Firstly, the entire document needs to replace CGA with CGS as CGS will be the paying entity (please confirm if I am wrong).  Please advise full name of CGS Included in the executed MOU.

 

 

 

On the other hand, below are our preliminary comments on the attached T&C: 

 

*	Clause 7.3: The cancellation terms appear unfair given the significant contract amount; the current provision implies that CGS cannot recover any payment if cancellation occurs after two weeks of order confirmation.  This is our Standard Cancellation Clause, and is irrespective of the contact amount, since we have commitments to our suppliers once we place the order. @Mohammed <mailto:MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com> , I would suggest confirming this with management, as we are certainly not in favor of this.(Confirm, as this was initially reviewed by the management, which is typically the case with any manufacturing orders.

chunks.text:
uggest confirming this with management, as we are certainly not in favor of this.(Confirm, as this was initially reviewed by the management, which is typically the case with any manufacturing orders. )

*	Clause 6.3: The payment schedule needs to be confirmed taking into account that construction at the site is still in its early stages. Our agreed upon payment  terms with Chalhoub Group for Projects is 50% Down Payment, and 50% on Completion of Installation. Given the size of this Project, and in light of our Partnership, we opted for 4 milestones Payments. @Mohammed <mailto:MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com> , I will let you confirm the payment terms, this comment was initially addressed to you. (Confirm, as this has already been agreed upon with the project team. I am looping in @Samer Faraj <mailto:Samer.Faraj@chalhoub.com>  to see if he has any concerns that need to be highlighted )

*	Moreover, the late payment penalty is illegal in KSA and should be excluded. Re-Phrased “Span Trading LLC shall be entitled to charge late penalty fees on overdue invoices from the date when payment becomes due until the date of payment. Fees will be calculated and capped at 11% annually”. Late payment penalty is neither legal nor enforceable in KSA, please exclude. (Aligned as long it is 100% legal concern )

*	Moreover, the last provision seems unacceptable as SPAN should not have the unilateral right to invoice the full amount if we fail to secure authorities' approvals; CGS should in fact have the right to cancel in such cases.  This is related only to a delay for installation of more than 60 days due to site non readiness, then Span has the right to invoice the balance amount less 10% which is the cost to cover installation.

Clause 6.6.2 only addresses potential delays. CGS should still have the right to take action in the event of any other breaches by SPAN. Please ensure that this clause protects the interests of both parties.
*	Clause 7.16.2: No action should be feasible for SPAN without granting the other party a 30-day remedy period. Agreed OK. The option to cancel the agreement and retain all payments made by CGS must be excluded. CGS should only be liable for the portion executed by SPAN.  Same rules of cancellation applies here, they cannot be different. Agreed in the case of a breach by CGS. However, breaches by SPAN would entitle CGS to recover all amounts paid for any portion not executed by SPAN prior to termination.
*	Clause 7.17: Competent courts should be in KSA, with applicable laws being those of KSA.  Prefer to keep it in UAE, since Chalhoub Head Office and Span are located in UAE. However, if you insist on changing it to KSA, it is fine with us. It needs to be KSA since CGS is based in KSA and the installation is in KSA.
*	Clause 7.18: We do not agree to any non-solicitation clause given the Group's size and the practical difficulty of enforcing it. This has been always in place and agreed upon with Chalhoub Group. Below snapshot from latest signed contact for your reference. We cannot remove it.  @Mohammed <mailto:MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com> , are you comfortable with this? We do not typically agree to this, but if it was already agreed upon in the past, it would be more challenging to renegotiate at this stage. (This clause is present in all previous agreements with them; however, from my side, it is acceptable unless there is any legal impact )

Cc: Carlos Daoud <Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com <mailto:Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com> >; Basmah Bokhari <Basmah.Bokhari@chalhoub.com <mailto:Basmah.Bokhari@chalhoub.com> >; Sultan Ulhaq Mohammed <Sultanulhaq.Mohammed@chalhoub.com <mailto:Sultanulhaq.Mohammed@chalhoub.com> >; Bhaskar Sharma <Bhaskar.Sharma@chalhoub.com <mailto:Bhaskar.Sharma@chalhoub.com> >
Subject: RE: Tawreed Structural Installation - LOI for Span

 

Dear Mohammed, 

 

Firstly, the entire document needs to replace CGA with CGS as CGS will be the paying entity (please confirm if I am wrong). 

 

On the other hand, below are our preliminary comments on the attached T&C: 

 

*	Clause 3: The cancellation terms appear unfair given the significant contract amount; the current provision implies that CGS cannot recover any payment if cancellation occurs after two weeks of order confirmation. 
*	Clause 6.3: The payment schedule needs to be confirmed taking into account that construction at the site is still in its early stages. Moreover, the late payment penalty is illegal in KSA and should be excluded.

metadata.doc_id: C1QBJ5X - tawreed structural installation - loi for span\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\C1QBJ5X - tawreed structural installation - loi for span\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
Moreover, the late payment penalty is illegal in KSA and should be excluded. Moreover, the last provision seems unacceptable as SPAN should not have the unilateral right to invoice the full amount if we fail to secure authorities' approvals; CGS should in fact have the right to cancel in such cases. 
*	Clause 6.4: Is the timeline realistic considering that construction has just started? 
*	Clause 6.6.2: This clause must be removed. Any delay in delivering the services should be considered a breach on SPAN's part, entitling CGS to terminate and/or seek compensation. 
*	Clause 7.7.5: Is the monthly charge of AED 316,400 reasonable? It seems excessively high. 
*	Clause 7.8: What costs are expected if CGS postpones installation for any reason? Are these linked to the site non-availability charge referenced in Clause 7.7.5? 
*	Clause 7.11.8: Why is CGS committing to issuing visas for their team? 
*	Clause 7.11.11: Shouldn't transportation, food and lodging costs be covered by the agreed contract amount? 
*	Clauses 7.12.3 and 7.12.4: References to the UAE should be replaced with KSA. 
*	Clause 7.14: CGS details should align with those in the MOU. 
*	Clause 7.16: This should be mutual and include breaches by SPAN. 
*	Clause 7.16.2: No action should be feasible for SPAN without granting the other party a 30-day remedy period. The option to cancel the agreement and retain all payments made by CGS must be excluded. CGS should only be liable for the portion executed by SPAN. 
*	Clause 7.17: Competent courts should be in KSA, with applicable laws being those of KSA. 
*	Clause 7.18: We do not agree to any non-solicitation clause given the Group's size and the practical difficulty of enforcing it.

chunks.text:
*	Clause 7.18: We do not agree to any non-solicitation clause given the Group's size and the practical difficulty of enforcing it. 
*	Clause 7.19: This entire confidentiality section should be mutual. 
*	Clause 7.20.4: This provision must be excluded, agreeing to such a general waiver is not feasible for obvious reasons. 
*	Clause 8: The insurance provision needs to be carefully reviewed by the insurance team. 
*	Additional Clause: Include a clause related to the Chalhoub Partner Code in the T&C. 

 

Please request SPAN to share a revised version incorporating these changes, otherwise let them share a Word version and @Yazeed <mailto:Yazeed.Alawad@chalhoub.com> , with thanks, can assist and incorporate the changes directly into the T&C. 

 

Once we receive the revised version, please ensure it is carefully reviewed by the tax team to address any potential tax implications for payments made to a UAE-based entity.

 

Best, 

Sayed Adnan

To: Carlos Daoud <Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com <mailto:Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com> >
Cc: Elmehdi Tahabouamri <Elmehdi.Tahabouamri@chalhoub.com <mailto:Elmehdi.Tahabouamri@chalhoub.com> >; Mohammed Ibrahim Mahmoud <MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com <mailto:MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com> >; Yazeed Alawad <Yazeed.Alawad@chalhoub.com <mailto:Yazeed.Alawad@chalhoub.com> >
Subject: Tawreed Structural Installation - LOI for Span

 

Hi  @Carlos Daoud <mailto:Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com> 

 

Trust this email finds you well.

 

In Tawreed for inventory storage, we have to install Pallet racks on the ground floor and a 2-level pick tower on the mezzanine. For this SOW, we have concluded the negotiation with Span and we would like to share the LOI with them. Span’s Proposal is attached for your reference.

Hi Deven,

 

PFA the estimates received from Span’s side for Phase-1 and Phase-2 separately. A couple of points to consider here,

 

1.	There is a small change in the estimates for pallet racks and mezzanine pick tower, but the overall estimate (USD 1.2 million) is the same as that of earlier estimates if phase1 and phase 2 are considered together.

l change in the estimates for pallet racks and mezzanine pick tower, but the overall estimate (USD 1.2 million) is the same as that of earlier estimates if phase1 and phase 2 are considered together.

Apologies for the late reply, as we were undergoing tough discussions and negotiations with our factories to secure best competitive prices. Glad to inform you that we were successful to manage decent savings, which we happily transfer to you.

 

Please find herewith attached revised drawings, as per our latest discussions,  and respective revised prices for your kind perusal.

 

Pallet Racking:

1.	Total Project Pallet Positions = 18,554 PP
2.	Area 1:

a.       Total Pallet Positions: 8,265 PP

b.       Total Picking Levels: 960 Level

c.       Total Number of Pallets on Ground level for 2000 mm high pallets: 527 PP

3.	Area 2:

a.       Total Pallet Positions: 9,249 PP

b.       Total Number of Pallets on Ground level of 2000 mm high: 1500 PP

4.	Area 3 – DG:

a.       Total Pallet Positions: 1,040 PP

b.       Total Picking Levels: 100 Level

 

Price as per today’s rates: AED 2,562,998.00 (US Dollars $ 696,467)

The Above price includes the use of existing material that was last purchased for Riyadh Pallet Racking Project, and was considered for future re-use in this project.

The Above price includes the 1060 Picking Levels complete with Wire Mesh Decking.

Material Availability as per today: 10 – 12 Weeks from Order Confirmation

Installation Period: 3 – 4 Weeks from date of receipt of Material at Site.

 

Mezzanine:

1.	Total sq.m. for Area 4, Approximately 2,195 sq.m.
2.	Total Number of Bays = 1035 Bay.
3.	Total Number of Storage CBM = 11,304 CBM.

 

Price as per today’s rate: AED 1,988,920.00 (US Dollars $ 540,467.50)

Material Availability as per today: 10 – 14 Weeks from Order Confirmation

Material Availability as per today: 10 – 14 Weeks from Order Confirmation

Installation Period: 6 – 7 Weeks from date of receipt of Material at Site.

 

Total Project Price: AED 4,551,918.00 (US Dollars $ 1,236,934.50)

In light of our Long Term Partnership and our commitment to support you meeting your target prices, we hereby confirm Total Project Discounted Price at US Dollars $1,200,000.00

 

To be noted, and due to instability in steel prices and shipping rates, the above price is valid till 31 July 2024.

 

I hope we have correctly interpreted your requirements, I look forward to work with you on this project, and receive your valuable L.P.O

Meanwhile, I remain at your disposal for any additional information you may require.

 

 

 

Best Regards,

 

NADIM AL FAKIH

Sales Director – Warehouse Solutions

2.	Timeline of delivery and installation of Pallet Racks and Mezzanine pick tower

Subject: Re: Tawreed Project - DIP Visit

 

Hi Youssif

 

Thank you for your quick response. Just wanted to highlight that the RFQ was rolled out specifically for warehouse automation and extending the scope to design the overall warehouse for inbound and outbound/packing should be optional. I appreciate the direction from your management but it is extremely important for us to keep our focus limited to warehouse automation.

 

Scope of Work:

1.	Please consider data shard with RFQ for warehouse automation design.

chunks.text:
Please consider data shard with RFQ for warehouse automation design. This is critical for evaluation of any of the automation solutions.
2.	For VAS, decanting will happen post VAS in the VAS area and should not impact the denting throughput for automation. The space required for inbound and VAS is already considered as part of warehouse design and is out of scope for automation.
3.	For Grey market scanning, we have a master barcode available on the carton box. Hence, this should not impact the throughput during picking or replenishment.

 

I hope this clarifies most of your open points and we can expect your revised proposal early next week.

 

Regards

 

SHOAIB FARHAD​​​​

MANAGER ‑ TECH PRODUCTS

M.C.T. FZE

DUBAI

Our team has been in continuous and open meetings, actively working on incorporating the new inputs to update our data analysis.

Given the exclusion of PLV from the analysis, we are currently evaluating its impact on throughput and storage capacity.

 

Yes, PLVs should not be considered in automation but please consider the IB/OB throughput and storage requirement given in the RFQ sacrosanct. PLVs are already excluded from the RFQ. We would not advise reduction in throughput or storage.

Excluding PLV will have an impact on the throughput, numbers will be shared shortly.

Then we agree accordingly on the new throughputs.

 

Special Handling for Fragrances and Perfumes

Fragrances which require special treatment and must be stored in the DG area, are now under evaluation.

We are considering a separate solution for such goods and need to quantify the required storage capacity.

Under this same category, could you confirm if there are any aerosols, special creams, or oils that also require special storage conditions?

Essentially, we need to identify all other categories that fall under DG.

 

We have asked for the product categories that might be considered as hazardous from our consultants. Please provide us with both the options

*	Excluding probable hazardous products from automation.
*	Considering all the probable hazardous product categories from RFQ in automation, keeping the throughput and storage requirements in line with the RFQ. (Suggestion would be to dedicate locations for such categories in the automation solution itself with proper safety norms)

 

I have attached the list of SKUs for both B2B and B2C, please can you add your input on the SKUs:

chunks.text:
I have attached the list of SKUs for both B2B and B2C, please can you add your input on the SKUs:

*	SKUs that will require special treatment – Not Applicable. Our storage is generally temperature controlled covering all SKU types.
*	Special storage in a vault – Not applicable at the moment. Our assumption is that automation itself will act as a secure storage since entry and exit of staff will be prohibited in that area. Picking and replenishment stations will be under CCTV monitoring for an extra layer of protection. Any maintenance activity in that area will happen in the presence of our security staff.
*	Special storage conditions (upright position)  - Always upright for perfumes, cream, oil, lotion etc. basically all SKUs which are leakage prone. No special requirement as this will be handled operationally.
*	Special Storage Environment under DG area  - We will provide you with the DG area storage norms from our consultant.
*	Any other input that should be considered in designing the warehouse – We will share relevant points if we come across any.

 

B2B Business in Saudi

As per your input, box picking accounts for 20% of the B2B business in Saudi.

We are quantifying this in terms of storage and throughput, as we might consider a separate solution for this operation.

 

Yes, 20%-24% of the B2B orders will have one or more boxes while picking. Please note that if an order has a mix of box picking and loose picking wherein boxes are picked from a separate automation, we need to have a provision to consolidate the order. Look forward to receiving the final proposal from Span.

Look forward to receiving the final proposal from Span.

Noted.

 

Upcoming Deliverables and Questions

 

Racking Proposal

Based on our meeting on Monday and as shared by Nadim, you will receive the racking proposal next week applying the new modifications. 

However, please note that proposed racking is still generic with potential modifications may affect the racking configuration.

The impact will be coming from the new figures coming from updated data analysis.

 

Request you to share the quotation along with relevant drawings by Tuesday. Please incorporate the suggested changes in line with our discussion.

1.	Considering the utilization of rack material (pick face racks or separators etc.) from our existing DCs in KSA for the pallet rack area
2.	Considering the agreed reduction of more than 55-60% of locations from the mezzanine pick tower

Noted.

 

Specific Queries

*	Inbound Data:

	*	As per the visit, we have multiple activities at the receiving area that will impact the flow and will require space for multiple operational activities. 
	*	Please can you share with us KSA raw data for inbound operations following the same period as the outbound.

 

Receiving, VAS and QC of inbounded items will happen before the putaway in automation. It’s not going to impact the size of automation or would necessitate any special space requirement.

I have attached 2023 data for both Riyadh and Jeddah inbound for the entire year for your reference.

The recommendations from our Top management team are to design the full facility in terms of throughput and storage based on detailed understanding of the current operations driven by data analytics.

he recommendations from our Top management team are to design the full facility in terms of throughput and storage based on detailed understanding of the current operations driven by data analytics.

Our duty and commitment is to provide our partner the right solutions across the facility in line with your transformation strategy, and not just focused on specific automation application.

 

*	Fashion Items:

	*	From the data, how can we identify which fashion items should be hanged?
	*	Is it related to a specific brand?

If we can spot the hanged items, then we assume that the remaining items will be folded.

 

Please consider folded apparel in automation. Data does not have any GOH.
Noted.
On the mezzanine structure, you have requested to consider GOH locations. Is it enough?

             

 

*	Jewellery Storage:

	*	Are there any special storage requirements for jewellery? Not required
	*	For example, should high-value items be placed in a vault? Vault is not applicable.

 

*	Gray Market Scanning:

	*	How can we identify the Gray market scanning SKUs or brands (those items that require single piece scanning)?
	*	Is it considered for both Beauty and Fashion items?

 

Gray market picking will be exactly similar to non-grey SKUs. Picking can happen at a pallet level/box level/inner pack level/sku level. Relevant information on Grey market SKUs will be pushed from WMS.
Is it possible to quantify the total percentage of shipped quantity that require scanning every single item?
This will impact on the picking operation as it will require more time to process, so maybe more people or more stations.

Data Analysis and Updates

Our team has been in continuous and open meetings, actively working on incorporating the new inputs to update our data analysis.

Given the exclusion of PLV from the analysis, we are currently evaluating its impact on throughput and storage capacity.

 

Special Handling for Fragrances and Perfumes

Fragrances which require special treatment and must be stored in the DG area, are now under evaluation.

We are considering a separate solution for such goods and need to quantify the required storage capacity.

Under this same category, could you confirm if there are any aerosols, special creams, or oils that also require special storage conditions?

Essentially, we need to identify all other categories that fall under DG.

 

I have attached the list of SKUs for both B2B and B2C, please can you add your input on the SKUs:

*	SKUs that will require special treatment,
*	Special storage in a vault
*	Special storage conditions (upright position)
*	Special Storage Environment under DG area
*	Any other input that should be considered in designing the warehouse

 

B2B Business in Saudi

As per your input, box picking accounts for 20% of the B2B business in Saudi.

We are quantifying this in terms of storage and throughput, as we might consider a separate solution for this operation.

 

Upcoming Deliverables and Questions

 

Racking Proposal

Based on our meeting on Monday and as shared by Nadim, you will receive the racking proposal next week applying the new modifications.

Hi @Carlos Daoud <mailto:Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com> 

 

I hope you are hale and hearty.

 

Please let us know by when the LOI and draft MOU will be ready.

It is critical for us to share at least the LOI quickly to lock the proposed quote given by Span. We don’t want to see the cost of project going up owing to varying steel prices :)

 

Thanks

Sent: Thursday, 14 November 2024 1:11 PM
To: Carlos Daoud <Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com <mailto:Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com> >
Cc: Elmehdi Tahabouamri <Elmehdi.Tahabouamri@chalhoub.com <mailto:Elmehdi.Tahabouamri@chalhoub.com> >; Mohammed Ibrahim Mahmoud <MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com <mailto:MohamedIbrahim.Mahmoud@chalhoub.com> >; Yazeed Alawad <Yazeed.Alawad@chalhoub.com <mailto:Yazeed.Alawad@chalhoub.com> >
Subject: Tawreed Structural Installation - LOI for Span

 

Hi  @Carlos Daoud <mailto:Carlos.Daoud@chalhoub.com> 

 

Trust this email finds you well.

 

In Tawreed for inventory storage, we have to install Pallet racks on the ground floor and a 2-level pick tower on the mezzanine. For this SOW, we have concluded the negotiation with Span and we would like to share the LOI with them. Span’s Proposal is attached for your reference.

Regards
